isis.stitle: TSI 05-12-40 - EPA Emergency Fuel Usage Waiver

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to all International® diesel engines. In response to refinery damage caused by Hurricane Katrina, the EPA has issued a temporary fuel usage waiver to eliminate potential fuel shortages.

The distribution of non-road application high-sulfur fuel (2000 ppm sulfur) will be temporarily permitted for highway applications until November 20, 2005. Additionally, the waiver temporarily eliminates the requirement of adding red dye to high-sulfur fuel as an identifier.

Prior to hurricane damage assessment, the EPA initially issued a waiver permitting the distribution of high-sulfur fuel throughout the United States. The waiver currently applies to the District of Columbia and 23 States.

International Truck and Engine Corporation does not recommend the use of high-sulfur fuel for all International® diesel engines.
The use of high-sulfur fuel can cause corrosive damage to air system components on engines with Exhaust Gas Recirculation (EGR) system and reduce lubrication oil life on all engines.

caution.para: Use of high-sulfur fuel can result in engine damage. Using high-sulfur fuel will void expressed or implied warranty by International Truck and Engine Corporation on components affected by high-sulfur fuel use.

item.para: Consumers who unknowingly have used high-sulfur fuel
Consumers who have knowingly used high-sulfur fuel
Consumers who have not used the high-sulfur fuel

svcproc.title: Corrective Action
svcproc.para: Given these exceptional and temporary circumstances, International Truck and Engine Corporation offers the following guidance to ensure your engine continues to perform properly:

step1.para: Ensure you know the exact fuel you are introducing into your fuel system.
If you think or know you have used high-sulfur fuel, do the following:

item.para: Reduce oil drain and filter (oil and fuel) service intervals by 50%.
Applications requiring significant idle time (boom trucks, etc.) should ensure the engine is driven at rated speed for a significant period of time at days end.

Bringing the engine to full operating temperature once a day will help reduce the adverse corrosive effects of combined condensation and sulfur. This will additionally ensure the vehicle catalytic converter operates properly.
If your engine has an EGR system, have your engine inspected by technicians for potential corrosive damage to intake manifold.
Replace any intake manifolds with signs of corrosion. Failure to replace may result in corrosive flakes being introduced into the air management system and create excessive power cylinder wear.

svcproc.para: International Truck and Engine Corporation will continue to update and advise our customers on future EPA waivers as circumstances dictate.
